title: In this sentence, 'I don't have money to go to the doctor', is 'to go to the doctor' grammatically modifying 'money'? - Quora

response.answer_text: One rule of thumb when diagramming sentence is to assume that, if it looks like an ambiguous phrase might either be adverbial or adjectival, the normal default is to place it under the verb as an adverbial modifier unless the sense of the sentence clearly shows it modifies something else. So, which is being modified here—the verb combination “don’t have” or the “money”? Here, I don’t think it’s adverbial, telling me about how you have or don’t have something. Instead, it appears to be functionally adjectivally, describing the type of money you don’t have or the intended purpose of the money. So, yes, I think it is modifying money based on the sense of the given sentence.
